For music for individual dances, see the dance form, e.g., [Morris dances (Music).]"], "genres":[], "variantLabels":[], "languages":[], "relateds":["Dance music", "Folk music"], "occupations":[], $aFolk songs"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk literature", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026342", "aLabel":"Folk literature", "vLabel":"Oral literature", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026342", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "notes":["Works based on oral traditions."], "genres":["Oral literatureOral literature", "Traditional literatureTraditional literature"], "variantLabels":["Oral literature", "Traditional literature"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Literature"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Encyclopædia Britannica online, Apr. 8, 2013 (folk literature, also called folklore or oral tradition, the lore (traditional knowledge and beliefs) of cultures having no written language. It is transmitted by word of mouth and consists, as does written literature, of both prose and verse narratives, poems and songs, myths, dramas, rituals, proverbs, riddles, and the like.)", "found : Southern Connecticut State University website Literature for children, viewed Apr. 8, 2013 (Folk literature. Definition: Folk or traditional literature is the collection of tales passed from generation to generation and from the old to the young by word of mouth (also called the oral tradition). Folk literature is believed to be people's efforts to organize their experiences into meaningful patterns. Folk literature includes fairy tales, myths, legends, fables, tall tales, and other oral traditions of preliterate societies.)", "found : Harmon, W. A handbook to literature, c2009 (Folklore. Folklore includes myths, legends, stories, riddles, proverbs, nursery rhymes, charms, spells, omens, beliefs of all sorts, popular ballads, cowboy songs, plant lore, animal lore, and customs dealing with birth, initiation, courtship, marriage, medicine, work, amusements, and death.)", "found : LCSH, Oct. 22, 2014 (Folk literature. UF Oral literature. BT Literature)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Literature"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk literature"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk tales", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026344", "aLabel":"Folk tales", "vLabel":"Folktales", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026344", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "notes":["Short narratives of uncertain origin that are based on oral tradition."], "genres":["FolktalesFolktales", "MärchenMärchen"], "variantLabels":["Folktales", "Märchen"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Fiction", "Folk literature"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Harmon, W. A handbook to literature, c2009: Folktale (A short narrative handed down through oral tradition, with various tellers and groups modifying it, so that it acquires cumulative authorship. Most folktales eventually move from oral tradition to written form) Tale (A relatively simple narrative. Formerly, no very real distinction was made between the tale and the short story. Tale, however, has always been a more general term, because short story has been reserved for fictional narratives having a conscious structure and tale has been used loosely for any short narrative, either true or fictitious)", "found : Wheeler, K. Literary terms and definitions, via WWW, Jan. 22, 2013: Folktale (Folktales are stories passed along from one generation to the next by word-of-mouth rather than by a written text) Folklore (Many works of literature originated in folktales before the narratives were written down. Examples in American culture include the story of George Washington chopping down the cherry tree; George Washington throwing a silver dollar across the Potomac river; Paul Bunyon cutting lumber with his blue ox, Babe; Pecos Bill roping a twister; and Johnny Appleseed planting apples across the west over a 120-year period)", "found : Kennedy, X.J. The Longman dictionary of literary terms, c2006 (Tale. A word originating from the Old English talu, or \"speech,\" a tale is a short, anonymous narrative without a complex plot or three-dimensional characters. An ancient form of narrative found in folklore and oral tradition, tales present basic stories with simple motivations, their literary power stemming from supernatural elements, twists of fate, and comic or tragic outcomes. A tale differs from a short story by its tendency to linear plotting and flat and stock characters, a distinction that British writer A.E. Coppard attributes to the fact that a story is something that is written and a tale is something that is told. The ambition of a tale is usually similar to that of a yarn: a concentrated revelation of the marvelous, comical, and ironic, rather than the careful representation of the everyday world.)", "found : Dictionary.com, Apr. 11, 2013: folk tale (noun, 1. a tale or legend originating and traditions among a people or folk, especially one forming part of the oral tradition of the common people. 2. any belief or story passed on traditionally, especially one considered to be false or based on superstition. Also, folk-tale. Also called folk story)", "found : Cuddon, J.A. A dictionary of literary terms and literary theory, 1998 (Märchen. A German term for a folk tale or fairy story. The classic collection is that made by the Grimm brothers early in the 19th c.)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Fiction", "Folk literature"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk tales"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Turbo-folk (Music)", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014027151", "aLabel":"Turbo-folk (Music)", "vLabel":"", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014027151", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":[], "variantLabels":[], "languages":[], "relateds":["Popular music"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Work cat: Cvoro, U., Turbo-folk music and cultural representations of national identity in former Yugoslavia, 2014.", "found : Balkan Insight WWW site, Dec. 11, 2013 (News, Oct. 6, 2011. Skopje Bans \"Turbo Folk\" on Public Transport; Turbo Folk music emerged in late 1980s and 90s in Serbia as a sub-genre of Balkan folk music blended with dance and pop elements and quasi-meaningful lyrics. Although widely rejected by music critics as plain kitsch, this blend soon became mainstream among the masses in many Balkan states)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Popular music"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aTurbo-folk (Music)"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk dances", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2023026110", "aLabel":"Folk dances", "vLabel":"Choreographic folklore", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2023026110", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":["Choreographic folkloreChoreographic folklore", "Ethnic dancesEthnic dances", "Folkloric dancesFolkloric dances", "Traditional dancesTraditional dances"], "variantLabels":["Choreographic folklore", "Ethnic dances", "Folkloric dances", "Traditional dances"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Dance"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Work cat: Folk dances of different nations, 1926: volume 1, title page (containing 23 very easy dances; other more difficult folk dances published in volumes II & III)", "found : Rwanda traditional dance [VR], 2008: opening frames (This DVD holds a variety of dances; the list includes a variety of dancing styles among which many were performed during the closing ceremony of the Pan African Dance Festival (FESPAD); most of these dances are performed on the beats of drums)", "found : Oxford dictionary of dance (2 ed.), via Oxford reference, viewed October 17, 2023 (Folk dance; Term denoting any kind of dance which has been developed within a traditional community, rather than being created by a choreographer or teacher. Steps and patterns are passed on from one generation to another, gradually undergoing change. Many folk dances have their origins in ritual--fertility, marriage, religious, or war--and express the character of the community who dance them. The term was coined in the 18th century to distinguish 'peasant' dance forms from those of the upper classes, but the distinction itself dates back to the 15th century when ballroom dances first began to emerge as separate forms)", "found : Oxford music online, viewed October 17, 2023 (Folk dance: Recreational dance of the common people of a country or region. The term refers specifically to the traditional dances of European peoples. For characteristic dances of other cultures, such as those indigenous to Africa, Asia, North and South America, Oceania, and Australia, the term \"ethnic dance\" or \"traditional dance\" is preferred)", "found : Oxford English dictionary, viewed January 4, 2024 (folk-dance; A dance of popular origin; the music for such a dance)", "found : Dance words, 1995: page 36 (ethnic dance: the dance of a group \"which holds in common genetic, linguistic, and cultural ties with special emphasis on cultural tradition; said of every dance form and argued to include ballet) page 37 (folk dance: dance in a society which is, in contrast to a so-called primitive society, not autonomous but one which is in symbiotic relationship with the larger society with which it constantly interacts) page 38 (folk dance: dance performed for recreational and social purpose; traditional dance; said to have three types in England: the Morris, the word dance, and the country dance)", "found : Wikidata, viewed October 3, 2024 (Folk dance; also known as: traditional dance; ethnic dance; сhoreographic folklore; folkloric dance)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Dance"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk dances"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk song texts", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2017026145", "aLabel":"Folk song texts", "vLabel":"", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2017026145", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":[], "variantLabels":[], "languages":[], "relateds":["Song texts"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Work cat.: Chansons populaires, 1970 (texts of Cambodian folk songs in French)", "found : Lomax, A. Folk song style and culture, 1978: table of contents (Folk song texts as culture indicators)", "found : Gordon, R.W. Manuscript collections of American folksong texts, 1978.", "found : Spinner, L. Cantata on German folksong texts, ©1978."], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Song texts"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk song texts"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk poetry", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026343", "aLabel":"Folk poetry", "vLabel":"Oral traditional poetry", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026343", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "notes":["Poems that are composed and transmitted via oral tradition."], "genres":["Oral traditional poetryOral traditional poetry", "Traditional poetry, OralTraditional poetry, Oral"], "variantLabels":["Oral traditional poetry", "Traditional poetry, Oral"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Folk literature", "Poetry"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : The new Princeton encyclopedia of poetry and poetics, 1993: p. 863 (Oral poetry, especially oral traditional poetry, is poetry composed and transmitted mainly but not exclusively by people who cannot read or write. Oral poetry is traditional when each generation has received it orally from the preceding one, back to the dawn of poetry, and transmits it to the next as long as the tradition lives. Oral poetry has its own methods of composition and transmission which differentiate it from written literature.)", "found : Folklore : electronic journal of folklore, v. 33, viewed Jan. 11, 2013: p. 86 (Seven factors of folk poetry: i. It is a social activity. ii. It is an activity which belongs to all people. iii. It may relate to all aspects of life. iv. Its forms are very numerous and non-static. v. It is, in essence, an oral activity. vi. It communicates messages in a direct and colourful manner, with the emphasis on narration and communication. vii. Folk poetry is functional, applied poetry.)", "found : Encyclopedia of American poetry. The Nineteenth century, 1998: p. 347 (Folk poetry typically circulates orally, through recitations or songs)", "found : American folk poetry, 1974.", "found : LCSH, Oct. 22, 2014 (Folk poetry)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Folk literature", "Poetry"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk poetry"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk music", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026809", "aLabel":"Folk music", "vLabel":"Ethnic music", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026809", "rank":"661", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "notes":["Locally or regionally traditional music that was originally developed in performance and aurally transmitted in community contexts, and for music composed stylistically and/or ideologically within these traditions."], "genres":["Ethnic musicEthnic music", "Traditional musicTraditional music"], "variantLabels":["Ethnic music", "Traditional music"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Music"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Grove music online, viewed August 29, 2014 (Folk music; this concept has been defined and developed in multiple ways by collectors, scholars, and practitioners, within different geographical locations and in different historical periods; has been used both covertly and overtly in the construction and negation of identities in relation to class, nation, or ethnicity and continues to be the source of controversy and heated debate; Volkslied coined by Johann Gottfried Herder, characteristics include necessity of production by \"communal composition\" and an aesthetic of \"dignity\"; from the late 19th century onwards, the concept became increasingly crucial to the debates on nationalism; English folksong collector Cecil Sharp perceived folk music as only produced by artisan and labouring rural people; argued that continuity, variation, and selection were the three vital components of folksongs and that anonymous composition and oral transmission were defining elements; International Folk Music Council attempted a definition of folk music in 1955: \"the product of a musical tradition that has been evolved through the process of oral transmission\"; from the 1960s onwards, North Americans increasingly extended the meaning of \"folk music\" to include the musics of ethnic and racial communities; for European countries, New Grove distinguishes between \"art\" music, \"folk\" or \"traditional\" music and \"popular\" music)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Music"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk music"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk drama", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026341", "aLabel":"Folk drama", "vLabel":"Folk plays", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026341", "rank":"-2185", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "notes":["Amateur dramas based on folk traditions and local history."], "genres":["Folk playsFolk plays", "FolkdramaFolkdrama", "FolkplaysFolkplays"], "variantLabels":["Folk plays", "Folkdrama", "Folkplays"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Drama", "Folk literature"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : LCSH, Oct. 22, 2014 (Folk drama. UF Folk plays)", "found : Merriam-Webster online, Nov. 2, 2012 (Folklore definition--originating or traditional with the common people of a country or region and typically reflecting their lifestyle)", "found : The Oxford companion to the theatre, 1983 (Folk play. Under this heading may be grouped the rough-and-ready dramatic entertainments given at village festivals by the villagers themselves; derived from the dramatic tendencies inherent in primitive folk festivals, and were given on May-day, at Harvest Home, or at Christmas, when to the central theme of a symbolic death and resurrection, which comes from remotest antiquity, were added the names and feats of local worthies)", "found : OCLC, Apr. 19, 2013 (titles: Mexican folk plays; New anthology of contemporary Austrian folk plays; Epic and folk plays of the Yiddish theatre; An interim list of Nottinghamshire folk plays and related customs; Home to Canaan : a Negro folkplay from Bible narrative; Spanish folkplays of the San Juan Basin; Folkplays of Dingxian; European lyric folkdrama; Javanese folkdrama and social change; Origin, definition & introduction of Bengal's folkdrama; Cheshire folk drama; Efik folk drama; The folk drama of Ceylon; Introduction to Korean folk drama; Glimpses of Bengali folk dramas; Puppetry and folk dramas, for non-formal education; Six Nuevomexicano folk dramas for Advent season)", "found : The Columbia encyclopedia, 2013, via Credo Reference online, March 20, 2015: (folk drama, noncommercial, generally rural theater and pageantry based on folk traditions and local history. This form of drama, common throughout the world, declined in popularity in the West (although not in Asia) with the advent of printing, general literacy, and the increasing emphasis on the individual contribution to the drama of playwright, director, and actors. The mid-19th cent. witnessed a revival of folk drama in the United States and parts of Western Europe; regional history plays)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Drama", "Folk literature"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk drama"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk music radio programs", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2011026805", "aLabel":"Folk music radio programs", "vLabel":"Ethnic music radio programs", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2011026805", "rank":"-2185", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":["Ethnic music radio programsEthnic music radio programs", "Music radio programs, EthnicMusic radio programs, Ethnic", "Music radio programs, FolkMusic radio programs, Folk", "Music radio programs, TraditionalMusic radio programs, Traditional", "Traditional music radio programsTraditional music radio programs"], "variantLabels":["Ethnic music radio programs", "Music radio programs, Ethnic", "Music radio programs, Folk", "Music radio programs, Traditional", "Traditional music radio programs"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Radio programs"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Work cat.: Kieran Hanrahan's ten years of Céilí house [SR], 2005: disc label (21 tracks of live Irish traditional music from the RTÉ Libraries and Archives)", "found : Céilí House home page, Nov. 9, 2011 (\"Céilí House is one of RTÉ Radio's most popular programmes of traditional Irish music and song\"; site includes audio links to archived recordings of all the shows from 2004 to the present)", "found : TruMix home page, Nov. 9, 2011: Web radio browse + listen > By genre (Folk Music) About Trumix (\"TruMix (www.Trumix.com) provides access to Internet Radio and podcasts from around the world. You can download or play the podcasts straight from the website. You can create your own account and store your favourite podcasts and Internet radio stations, and choose from packaged selections of podcasts and music.\")", "found : LCSH (Folk music. UF Ethnic music; Traditional music)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Radio programs"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk music radio programs"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Ballads", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026648", "aLabel":"Ballads", "vLabel":"Folk ballads", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026648", "rank":"-2846", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "notes":["European and North American narrative songs that describe a dramatic episode in strophic form, often with a recurrent refrain."], "genres":["Folk balladsFolk ballads"], "variantLabels":["Folk ballads"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Narrative songs"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Friedman, A.B. The Viking book of folk ballads of ... 1956.", "found : Southern folk ballads, 1987-1988.", "found : Grove music online, viewed July 9, 2014 (Ballad; term used for a short popular traditional song that normally frames a narrative element. Scholars of the term's history and origin take it to signify a relatively concise composition known throughout Europe since the late Middle Ages, spreading later to the New World, notably the Americas: it combines narrative, dramatic dialogue and lyrical passages in strophic form sung to a rounded tune, and often includes a recurrent refrain. Performance is predominantly by solo singers, though choral and dance elements are known in some cultures.)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Narrative songs"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aBallads"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk punk music", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2019026031", "aLabel":"Folk punk music", "vLabel":"Punk folk music", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2019026031", "rank":"-3062", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":["Punk folk musicPunk folk music", "Rogue folk musicRogue folk music"], "variantLabels":["Punk folk music", "Rogue folk music"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Folk music", "Punk rock music"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Work cat.: Pogues (Musical group). Rum, sodomy & the lash, ℗1985 (folk punk music)", "found : Violent Femmes (Musical group). The blind leading the naked, ℗1986 (folk punk music)", "found : Haas, B.D. Performing folk punk, 2013, via WWW, viewed Feb. 19, 2019: p. 2 (folk punk music; folk punk performance, situated at the intersection of the folk and punk genres) p. 4 (folk punk combines elements offered by both folk and punk)", "found : Wikipedia, Feb. 19, 2019 (Folk punk (known in its early days as rogue folk); fusion of folk music and punk rock; popularized in the early 1980s by The Pogues in Britain, and by Violent Femmes in the United States; musicians performing their own compositions in the style of punk rock, but using additional folk instruments, such as mandolins, accordions, banjos or violins; includes subgenres Celtic punk and Gypsy punk)", "found : Folk punk, via rateyourmusic.com, Feb. 19, 2019 (Folk Punk describes Punk Rock with any kind of Folk influence. The most common influences are Celtic Folk Music (Celtic Punk), Romani Folk Music and Balkan Folk Music (Gypsy Punk); instrumentation of folk punk can either be as varied as its influences, ranging from traditional and acoustic instruments to a more typical punk rock set with electric guitars, bass, and drums; genre emerged in the early 1980s in the UK, most notably with the early releases of Billy Bragg and the Irish-British band The Pogues, who mixed traditional Irish songs with the aggressiveness of punk music; Another branch of folk punk developed in the 1980s in the US. Violent Femmes are commonly cited as a big influence on the development of this style. Unlike the Pogues in the UK, they did not base their sound on a fusion of traditional music with punk, instead creating a style that was closer to Contemporary Folk-influenced Folk Rock. This mix of acoustic instrumentation and punk rock was not much different from the Country-related genre of Cowpunk. The American style of folk punk continued to develop in the late 1990s and early 2000s)", "found : Folk punk music, via last.fm website, Feb. 19, 2019: Overview (Folk punk; genre (or set of genres) of music that combines elements of folk and punk rock music; in North American usage it describes fusion with American folk music; other blends of punk and folk/traditional genres may be described differently (e.g. Celtic punk), although the usage and delineation of such terms varies; usually focuses on political issues from the radical left and anarchist side of the spectrum, but often incorporates a personal perspective to these views; embraces a legacy of traditional folk music, typified by themes of working class solidarity and resistance in the face of the perceived problems of industrialization and modern capitalism. Some bands and artists play a style that is less folk-influenced, but use instruments not normally used in punk rock, like the violin, banjo, mandolin, or ukulele; The most famous British folk-punk band is the Pogues, who formed during the new wave of punk rock in the early 1980s and played a mix of traditional Irish folk songs, modern social commentary and songs of boozy hedonism)", "found : An introduction to folk-punk, via WWW, Feb. 19, 2019 (Folk-punk music is a combination of folk music and punk rock music; The Violent Femmes gave folk punk its fame in America during the 1980s; Many folk punk artists perform their own arrangements. They often arrange in the style of punk rock, but use traditional folk instruments, such as mandolins, banjos, violins, and accordions. Other instruments typically used include drums, washboard, bass guitar, and electric guitar. Throughout time, synthesizers have become more common within the folk punk community)", "found : The best folk punk bands, via Ranker website, Feb. 19, 2019 (folk punk bands; folk punk groups; punk folk bands)", "found : Grove music online, Feb. 19, 2019: Violent Femmes (Post-punk, folk-punk band. Inspired by punk rock, the Violent Femmes incorporated elements of folk, jazz, bluegrass, country, and rockabilly music into their minimal and frequently acoustic sound)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Folk music", "Punk rock music"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk punk music"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Folk-rock music", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2014026810", "aLabel":"Folk-rock music", "vLabel":"Ecology rock music", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2014026810", "rank":"-3608", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":["Ecology rock musicEcology rock music", "Electric folk musicElectric folk music", "Folkrock musicFolkrock music", "Soft rock (Folk-rock music)Soft rock (Folk-rock music)"], "variantLabels":["Ecology rock music", "Electric folk music", "Folkrock music", "Soft rock (Folk-rock music)"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Folk music", "Rock music"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Int. The org. was formerly known as the International Folk Music Council)", "found : Vassal, J. Electric children, 1976 (folkrock)", "found : The Electric muse, c1975 (the story of folk into rock)", "found : Hennepin (Folk-rock music)", "found : 9,000 words (folk-rock)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Folk music", "Rock music"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFolk-rock music"], "gacs":[]}}, {"suggestLabel":"Freak folk (Music)", "uri":"http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/gf2016026016", "aLabel":"Freak folk (Music)", "vLabel":"Acid folk (Music)", "sLabel":"", "code":"", "token":"gf2016026016", "rank":"-3773", "more":{"nonlatinLabels":[], "vernacularLabels":[], "rdftypes":["GenreForm", "SimpleType", "Authority"], "collections":["http://id.loc.gov/authorities/genreForms/collection_LCGFT_General"], "genres":["Acid folk (Music)Acid folk (Music)", "Psych folk (Music)Psych folk (Music)", "Psychedelic folk (Music)Psychedelic folk (Music)"], "variantLabels":["Acid folk (Music)", "Psych folk (Music)", "Psychedelic folk (Music)"], "languages":[], "relateds":["Folk music", "Popular music"], "occupations":[], "activityfields":[], "sources":["found : Work cat.: Have moicy!, 1991?, p1976 (Folk song compilation, predominantly freak-folk style, with some country-folk)", "found : Encarnacao, J. Punk aesthetics and new folk, 2013: p. 191 (freak folk) p. 193 (definitive of what came to be regarded as \"freak folk\", a lo-fi mix of songs and fragments) p. 215 (attributes range from vocal quirks to an uncomfortable intimacy by way of minimalism of production and musical arrangement, to album and track structures that challenge listeners' preconceptions of popular music. The \"freakishness\" extends to the anthropomorphic and pre-industrial ideas presented in the lyrics)", "found : Last.fm website, Aug. 26, 2015 (Freak Folk is a style that uses mainly acoustic instruments; mostly guitar (often in alternate tunings) and occasionally violin or flute, accompanied by percussion instruments such as bongos. Used correctly, it tends to refer to music with long instrumental/psychedelic passages (and that may utilize drones), or \"poppier\" folk music with elaborately baroque, psychedelic or oppressive atmospheres. It is a term associated with contemporary artists like Joanna Newsom, Cocorosie, Six Organs of Admittance, Akron/Family, Rio en Medio, Charalambides, and with '60s Acid Folk artists like the Holy Modal Rounders, The Incredible String Band, Tyrannosaurus Rex, The Godz and The Fugs.)", "found : Carew, A. Genre profile - freak-folk, via About.com website, Aug. 26, 2015 (Like so many musical genres, the parameters of 'freak folk' are ill-defined. But the ties that bind don't always seem to have a lot to do with music. Largely about reviving '60s ideology--as enshrined on LPs like Vashti Bunyan's glorious Just Another Diamond Day, which was reviled in its time for its hippyish daydreaming--the freak-folkers were sold on the imagined mythology of the hippies. ... The defining elements are often as aesthetic as they are about pure sound. Acoustic sounds are a must, and stringed instruments always work best if finger-picked. Lyrically, evoking the mythical and the pastoral is stock-in-trade. And that romanticism for the land picks up on the hippy spirit, and what might be the genre's most defining quality: sounding out of time. Defining albums: Vashti Bunyan, Just Another Diamond Day (1970); Linda Perhacs, Parallelograms (1970); Devendra Banhart, Oh Me Oh My... The Way the Day Goes By the Sun Is Setting Dogs Are Dreaming Lovesongs of the Christmas Spirit (2003); Joanna Newsom, The Milk-Eyed Mender (2004); Various, Golden Apples of the Sun (2004); Animal Collective, Sung Tongs (2004); Espers, II (2006))", "found : Wikipedia, Aug. 26, 2015 (Freak folk is a genre of folk music which uses mainly acoustic instrumentation, but introduces elements of avant-garde music, baroque pop, and psychedelic folk, often featuring uncommon sounds, lyrical themes, and vocal styles. Notable artists: Akron/Family; Angels of Light; Animal Collective; Birdengine; Bob Wiseman; Bowerbirds; Brian Smith; Cerberus Shoal; CocoRosie; Comus; The Decemberists; Devendra Banhart; Diane Cluck; Dirty Projectors; The Dodos; EMA; Exuma; Faun Fables; Futurebirds; Greg Weeks; Grizzly Bear; Hop Along; Joanna Newsom; Larkin Grimm; Rio en Medio; Sibylle Baier; Sufjan Stevens; King Buzzo; Timber Timbre; Tune-Yards; Vashti Bunyan; White Magic; Woods)", "found : R.E.M. (Musical group). Fables of the reconstruction, ℗1985 (freak folk music)", "found : AllMusic website, Dec. 11, 2019: Fables of the Reconstruction (Fables of the Reconstruction is creepy, rustic psychedelic folk, filled with eerie sonic textures) Rough Trade Shops - Psych Folk 2010 (Rough Trade Shops - Psych Folk 2010 collects twenty one, modern day troubadours doing their best to both honor and propel the genre that inspired them. Psych-folk, freak-folk, acid folk (whatever you want to call it) has enjoyed a mild renaissance over the last decade or so)", "found : Wikipedia, Dec. 11, 2019: Psychedelic folk (Psychedelic folk (sometimes acid folk or freak folk) is a loosely defined form of psychedelia that originated in the 1960s. It retains the largely acoustic instrumentation of folk, but adds musical elements common to psychedelic music; Psychedelic folk generally favors acoustic instrumentation although it often incorporates other instrumentation. Chanting, early music and various non-Western folk music influences are often found in psych folk. Much like its rock counterpart, psychedelic folk is often known for a peculiar, trance-like, and atmospheric sound, often drawing on musical improvisation and Asian influences. Its lyrics are often concerned with such subjects as the natural world, love and beauty and try to evoke a state of mind associated with the effects of psychedelic drugs; Freak folk is a loosely defined synonym or subgenre of psychedelic folk which involves acoustic sounds, pastoral and delightful lyrics, and a neo-hippie aesthetic)", "found : Cambridge dictionary online website, Dec. 11, 2019 (freak-folk (also freak folk): a type of folk music that uses mainly acoustic (= non-electric) instruments but includes some unusual and very modern sounds and styles)"], "locales":[], "birthplaces":[], "birthdates":[], "deathdates":[], "lcclasss":[], "lcclasses":[], "hasRelatedAuthoritys":[], "broaders":["Folk music", "Popular music"], "sees":[], "hasEarlierEstablishedForms":[], "hasLaterEstablishedForms":[], "useFors":[], "marcKeys":["155  $aFreak folk (Music)"], "gacs":[]}}]}
